- _The Loving Dominant_ by John Warren, Libby Warren

children.name: Glossary.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# Glossary

- **Co-regulation**: Mutual calming through relationship signals.
- **Attachment Bid**: A signal seeking connection (Gottman).
- **Parts**: Inner voices/roles in IFS.
- **Drama Triangle**: Dysfunctional relational roles.

children.name: Case Study Examples.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# Case Study Examples

## Example 1: Missed Bid (Gottman)

- One partner makes a subtle request for connection.
- The other misses or dismisses it.
- Analysis: Identify bid, missed attunement, nervous system states.

## Example 2: Protest/Withdraw Cycle (EFT)

- One partner protests, the other withdraws.
- Cycle escalates conflict.
- Analysis: Identify attachment protest, fear of abandonment, nervous system activation.

## Example 3: Parts Conflict (IFS)

- Speaker shows conflicting statements from different parts.
- Analysis: Map manager vs. exile dynamics.

- Drama Triangle: Victim, Rescuer, Persecutor
- Gottman: Bids, Repairs, Four Horsemen

children.name: GPT Master Prompt Example.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: GPT Relational Analysis Prompt

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You always leave when I need you.'
> B: 'I feel trapped when you cry.'
> A: 'So I‚Äôm too much for you.'
> B: 'I don‚Äôt know how to help.'

## Observations

- A‚Äôs Exile part: abandonment fear (IFS).
- B‚Äôs Firefighter part: escape strategy (IFS).
- Polyvagal: A sympathetic mobilization, B dorsal collapse.

## Dynamics

- Negative cycle: protest ‚Üî withdrawal.
- Roles oscillate: Victim ‚Üî Persecutor ‚Üî Withdrawn.

## Insights

- Invite parts language (IFS).
- Coach presence cues (Polyvagal/EFT).
- Translate judgments into needs/requests (NVC).

**Related:** [[Frameworks/Internal Family Systems (IFS)]], [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: NVC Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Nonviolent Communication (NVC)

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You‚Äôre selfish; you never think of me.'
> B: 'You‚Äôre always judging me.'
> A: 'I want you to show you care.'
> B: 'I do care, but I feel attacked.'
> A: 'I‚Äôm scared I don‚Äôt matter.'
> B: 'I want to get this right but I don‚Äôt know how.'

## Observations

- Judgments replace observations, triggering defensiveness.
- Feelings and needs not explicitly named.
- Requests absent or implied.

## Dynamics

- Criticism ‚Üî defensiveness loop (Gottman Horsemen).
- Escalation due to unmet needs and lack of clarity.

## Insights

- Translate to OFNR: observation, feeling, need, request.
- Model: 'When the dishes pile up, I feel overwhelmed; I need support; would you wash them tonight?'
- Practice empathy before problem-solving.

**Related:** [[Transactional Analysis]], [[Gottman Method]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: EFT Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You don‚Äôt care when I cry.'
> B: 'I do care‚ÄîI just freeze.'
> A: 'It feels like I‚Äôm alone with my feelings.'
> B: 'I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôll make it worse.'
> A: 'I need to feel you with me.'
> B: 'I want to be there; I‚Äôm scared and unsure how.'

## Observations

- Secondary emotions (criticism/defensiveness) mask primary emotions (fear, longing).
- Cycle: pursue (A) ‚Üî withdraw (B).
- Attachment needs unmet: accessibility, responsiveness, engagement.

## Dynamics

- Negative cycle organizes behavior and blocks bonding events.
- Both partners misread intent due to the cycle.

## Insights

- Name the cycle as the problem ('us vs. the cycle').
- Structure an enactment: A risks vulnerability; B responds with presence.
- Reinforce A.R.E. moments to build secure bonding.

**Related:** [[Attachment Theory]], [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

children.name: Conflict Prompt Example.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Analysis Prompt - Conflict

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You never listen to me!'
> B: 'You‚Äôre always criticizing me.'
> A: 'Because I feel ignored.'
> B: 'I shut down when you yell.'

## Observations

- A escalates with protest behaviors (anxious).
- B withdraws defensively (avoidant).
- Polyvagal: sympathetic mobilization ‚Üî dorsal collapse.

## Dynamics

- Criticism ‚Üî defensiveness loop (Gottman Horsemen).
- Drama Triangle roles: Persecutor ‚Üî Victim.

## Insights

- Coach A to soften startup with needs language (NVC).
- Coach B to signal presence before retreat.
- Name and interrupt the negative cycle.

**Related:** [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Attachment Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Containment Models Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Containment Models

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'We keep arguing past midnight.'
> B: 'I‚Äôm exhausted and say things I regret.'
> A: 'Let‚Äôs try a 30-minute cap and a pause word.'
> B: 'And a recap at the end.'

## Observations

- Lack of structure leads to overflow and reactivity.
- Fatigue reduces regulation and empathy.

## Dynamics

- Unbounded conflict expands; no shared closure.
- Both want containment to stay within tolerance.

## Insights

- Timebox hard topics; use timers and recap notes.
- Define pause words and cooldown protocols.
- Schedule debrief and next steps.

**Related:** [[Boundary Models]], [[Trauma-Informed Care]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Gottman Method Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Gottman Method

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You never appreciate what I do.'
> B: 'You always complain.'
> A: 'I just want a thank you.'
> B: 'I want you to stop attacking me.'
> A: 'Can we try something different?'

## Observations

- Four Horsemen present: criticism ‚Üî defensiveness.
- Bids for connection missed; maps of inner world thin.

## Dynamics

- Negative sentiment override; failed repairs.
- No rituals of connection in place.

## Insights

- Use softened startup and accept influence.
- Replace Horsemen with antidotes (e.g., build appreciation).
- Add daily 'stress-reducing conversation' ritual.

**Related:** [[Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)]], [[Attachment Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

children.name: Attachment Prompt Example.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Analysis Prompt - Attachment

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Why didn‚Äôt you text me back?'
> B: 'I felt overwhelmed and needed space.'
> A: 'It makes me feel like you don‚Äôt care.'
> B: 'I do care, I just freeze.'

## Observations

- A: anxious attachment protest.
- B: avoidant attachment withdrawal.
- Underlying need for security unspoken.

## Dynamics

- Pursue‚Äìwithdraw cycle escalates insecurity.
- Attachment bids misinterpreted.

## Insights

- Coach A to name need directly: reassurance.
- Coach B to give consistent micro-reassurances.
- Introduce rituals of connection (EFT, Gottman).

**Related:** [[Attachment Theory]], [[Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]

children.name: Repair Attempts Prompt Example.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I didn‚Äôt mean to snap earlier.'
> B: 'You always say that but never change.'
> A: 'I really am sorry.'
> B: 'I can‚Äôt trust it yet.'

## Observations

- A initiates repair attempt (apology).
- B‚Äôs defensive wall blocks acceptance.
- Flooding prevents receptivity (Polyvagal).

## Dynamics

- Missed repair attempt ‚Üí cycle continues.
- Trust deficit reinforces negative sentiment override.

## Insights

- Coach B to regulate before responding.
- Reinforce repair by pairing apology with action.
- Add structured debrief ritual after conflict.

**Related:** [[Gottman Method]], [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

children.name: Karpman Drama Triangle Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Karpman Drama Triangle

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You ruined the evening.'
> B: 'It‚Äôs all my fault; I‚Äôm useless.'
> C: 'A, stop attacking B‚ÄîI‚Äôll fix this.'
> A: 'Fine, I‚Äôll do everything myself.'

## Observations

- Roles active: Persecutor (A), Victim (B), Rescuer (C).
- Rapid role shifts likely if challenged.

## Dynamics

- Drama fueled by blame/rescue; no needs stated.
- Payoff: avoidance of vulnerability and responsibility.

## Insights

- Decline role invitations; name needs/requests.
- Shift to Empowerment Triangle (Creator/Coach/Challenger).
- Establish boundaries and clarity of responsibilities.

**Related:** [[Empowerment Triangle]], [[Transactional Analysis]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Liberation Psychology Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Liberation Psychology

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I‚Äôm the only person like me at work.'
> B: 'I don‚Äôt get why that matters in our team.'
> A: 'It affects how safe I feel speaking up.'
> B: 'I hadn‚Äôt considered that.'

## Observations

- Context of marginalization affects safety and voice.
- Micro-to-macro power dynamics shape interactions.

## Dynamics

- Silencing via lack of contextual empathy.
- Opportunity for critical consciousness and allyship.

## Insights

- Name context and power explicitly.
- Create structures for voice and safety.
- Co-design norms that counter structural risks.

**Related:** [[Intersectional Feminist Psychology]], [[Consent Culture]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Conflict Example.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Conflict Example

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You never help around the house!'
> B: 'Why are you always nagging me?'

## Observations

- A in sympathetic mobilization (Polyvagal).
- B defensive, possible dorsal withdrawal.
- IFS: A's 'Critic' part, B's 'Defender'.
- Attachment: anxious protest vs. avoidant shutdown.

## Dynamics

- Drama Triangle roles: A=Persecutor, B=Victim.
- Boundary blurring around chores/roles.

## Insights

- Reframe A's protest as a bid for connection.
- Coach B to acknowledge need before problem-solving.
- Suggest NVC reframing: 'I feel overwhelmed... I need shared support.'

children.name: Intersectional Feminist Psychology Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Intersectional Feminist Psychology

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'When jokes target my identity, I freeze.'
> B: 'We tease everyone; it‚Äôs not personal.'
> A: 'It lands differently for me.'
> B: 'I didn‚Äôt realize the impact.'

## Observations

- Overlapping identities shape harm and risk.
- Impact differs from intent; safety varies by context.

## Dynamics

- Normalization of harm via 'equal-opportunity' framing.
- Power-aware empathy missing.

## Insights

- Adopt impact-first feedback norms.
- Add consent checks for humor topics.
- Include identity-informed safety agreements.

**Related:** [[Liberation Psychology]], [[Consent Culture]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

children.name: Relational Theory Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Relational Theory

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I don‚Äôt feel like myself around you lately.'
> B: 'I‚Äôve been keeping things inside to avoid fights.'
> A: 'So we‚Äôre both hiding.'
> B: 'I miss feeling close and honest.'
> A: 'Me too; I want to try again.'

## Observations

- Mutuality reduced; authenticity suppressed to avoid conflict.
- Disconnections unaddressed; no explicit repair attempts.

## Dynamics

- Cycle of protective distance undermines growth-fostering connection.
- Both long for mutual empathy and authenticity.

## Insights

- Name the disconnection; schedule structured repair dialogues.
- Practice mutual empathy rounds (speak/listen/reflect).
- Re-anchor norms: authenticity with care.

**Related:** [[Consent Culture]], [[Attachment Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

children.name: Narrative Therapy Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Narrative Therapy

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Procrastination ruins my life.'
> B: 'So the Problem convinces you to delay?'
> A: 'It tells me I‚Äôll fail anyway.'
> B: 'When have you acted despite it?'
> A: 'When I text a friend to co-work.'

## Observations

- Externalizing the Problem separates identity from struggle.
- Unique outcomes reveal competencies and values.

## Dynamics

- Story shifts from defect to preference and skill.
- Audience/witnessing consolidates change.

## Insights

- Name the Problem‚Äôs tactics and counter-practices.
- Collect exceptions; re-author preferred identity.
- Invite witnesses to thicken the preferred story.

**Related:** [[Frameworks/Internal Family Systems (IFS)]], [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Attachment Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Attachment Theory

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You didn‚Äôt text me back before bed.'
> B: 'I needed quiet after the meeting.'
> A: 'Silence makes me feel abandoned.'
> B: 'When I feel pressure, I shut down.'
> A: 'I just want to know you‚Äôre there for me.'
> B: 'I want that too‚ÄîI get scared I‚Äôll say the wrong thing.'

## Observations

- A shows anxious hyperactivation (protest bids).
- B shows avoidant deactivation (withdrawal).
- Both signal attachment needs indirectly.

## Dynamics

- Pursue‚Äìwithdraw loop fueled by misinterpretation of bids.
- Lack of explicit reassurance routines.

## Insights

- Create a predictable 'goodnight check-in' ritual (A.R.E.).
- Coach A to express needs directly without accusation.
- Coach B to provide short, reliable responsiveness signals.

**Related:** [[Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)]], [[Gottman Method]], [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]

children.name: Repair Attempt Example.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Repair Attempt Example

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I'm sorry I snapped at you earlier.'
> B: 'Yeah, whatever.'

## Observations

- A offers repair attempt (apology).
- B dismissive, still in defensive state.
- Polyvagal: A ventral, B sympathetic/dorsal.
- Attachment: A secure-ish, B avoidant protest.

## Dynamics

- Missed repair attempt increases cycle.
- Possible flooding prevents receptivity.

## Insights

- Coach B to pause and regulate before responding.
- Reinforce value of repair attempts.
- Encourage ritual of debrief after conflict.

children.name: Empowerment Triangle Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Empowerment Triangle

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'This problem is impossible.'
> B: 'What‚Äôs one small next step we could try?'
> A: 'Maybe we can draft a plan.'
> B: 'I can ask a few guiding questions.'
> A: 'Challenge me if I avoid the hard parts.'

## Observations

- Creator stance replaces Victim posture.
- Coach uses inquiry; Challenger sets growth edges.

## Dynamics

- Agency increases; blame decreases.
- Collaborative problem-solving emerges.

## Insights

- Reframe 'problem' ‚Üí 'project' with clear scope.
- Use coaching questions before advice.
- Offer caring challenge with consent.

**Related:** [[Karpman Drama Triangle]], [[Systems Thinking]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

children.name: Internal Family Systems (IFS).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Internal Family Systems (IFS)

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You never support me when I‚Äôm stressed.'
> B: 'That‚Äôs unfair‚ÄîI do a lot for you.'
> A: 'But when I cry, you disappear.'
> B: 'A part of me just freezes and wants to leave.'
> A: 'And a part of me feels abandoned all over again.'

## Observations

- A‚Äôs Exile (fear of abandonment) blends with Critic part.
- B‚Äôs Firefighter part avoids emotional overwhelm.
- Neither speaks from Self-energy; polarization dominates.

## Dynamics

- Protectors collide: Critic vs. Avoidant Firefighter.
- Underlying Exile pain unseen by both partners.

## Insights

- Invite parts language: 'A part of me‚Ä¶' instead of accusations.
- Pause for unblending and Self-access.
- Encourage Self-to-Self dialogue: curiosity, compassion.

**Related:** [[Narrative Therapy]], [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Systems Thinking Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Systems Thinking

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Why do our fights always spiral?'
> B: 'Because you won‚Äôt drop things.'
> A: 'I push because you avoid.'
> B: 'I avoid because you push.'
> A: 'We‚Äôre stuck in a loop.'
> B: 'I don‚Äôt know how to change it.'

## Observations

- Reinforcing feedback loop: pursue ‚Üí withdraw ‚Üí pursue (stronger) ‚Üí withdraw (deeper).
- Delay effects: post-conflict distance increases future sensitivity.

## Dynamics

- Attribution error: each blames the other‚Äôs personality, not the loop.
- No leverage points identified.

## Insights

- Insert a timed pause as a balancing loop (structured break).
- Add meta-communication checkpoints (What loop are we in?).
- Small experiments; measure system response rather than blame.

**Related:** [[Relational Theory]], [[Karpman Drama Triangle]], [[Gottman Method]]

children.name: Boundary Models Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Boundary Models

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Please don‚Äôt read my messages without asking.'
> B: 'I was worried and checked because you were distant.'
> A: 'That crossed a line for me.'
> B: 'I understand; I won‚Äôt do that again.'

## Observations

- Boundary breach justified by anxiety.
- Repair initiated through acknowledgment.

## Dynamics

- Porous boundary rationalized as care.
- Trust erosion unless limits clarified.

## Insights

- State boundary + impact + expectation.
- Negotiate access rules and check-ins.
- Reinforce that boundaries protect connection.

**Related:** [[Consent Culture]], [[Containment Models]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

children.name: Transactional Analysis Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Transactional Analysis

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You‚Äôre late again!'
> B: 'Stop treating me like a child.'
> A: 'If you respected me, you‚Äôd be on time.'
> B: 'Maybe if you weren‚Äôt so controlling‚Ä¶'

## Observations

- A in Critical Parent; B in Rebellious Child.
- Crossed transactions escalate conflict.

## Dynamics

- Game invitation: 'Now I‚Äôve Got You, You Son of a‚Ä¶'.
- Stroke economy skewed toward negative strokes.

## Insights

- Name ego states; invite Adult-to-Adult.
- Make clean contracts: who/what/when/how.
- Balance appreciation with clear requests.

**Related:** [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]], [[Karpman Drama Triangle]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Polyvagal Example.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Polyvagal Theory

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Why are you ignoring me?'
> B: 'I just can‚Äôt deal with this right now.'
> A: 'So you‚Äôre shutting me out again.'
> B: 'I feel trapped when you raise your voice.'
> A: 'I only raise my voice because I feel desperate.'

## Observations

- A escalates into sympathetic mobilization (fight energy).
- B shifts into dorsal vagal shutdown (avoidance).
- Cycle of pursue (A) vs withdraw (B).

## Dynamics

- Mismatched states lead to misattunement.
- Both partners interpret survival strategies as rejection.

## Insights

- Encourage explicit 'pause' agreements when dysregulated.
- B can signal presence nonverbally to reduce A‚Äôs panic.
- A can soften protest with needs language (NVC).

**Related:** [[Attachment Theory]], [[Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]

children.name: Trauma-Informed Care Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Trauma-Informed Care

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I can‚Äôt handle surprise feedback sessions.'
> B: 'We thought spontaneity kept it casual.'
> A: 'It spikes my anxiety.'
> B: 'Let‚Äôs schedule and share agenda ahead of time.'

## Observations

- Predictability and choice are core to safety.
- Unexpected intensity triggers hypervigilance.

## Dynamics

- Good intent without safety design undermines trust.
- Opportunity to embed choice/collaboration.

## Insights

- Add transparency: agendas, timing, opt-outs.
- Offer alternatives and pacing options.
- Use strengths-based, non-pathologizing framing.

**Related:** [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Consent Culture]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Somatic Experiencing Example (Long).md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Somatic Experiencing

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'My chest tightens when we argue.'
> B: 'My stomach drops and I go numb.'
> A: 'I can‚Äôt think clearly.'
> B: 'I want to run away.'
> A: 'Maybe we can slow down.'

## Observations

- High activation; limited cognitive bandwidth.
- Incomplete defensive responses (fight/flight/freeze).

## Dynamics

- Escalation sustained by unprocessed activation.
- Attempts to resolve content without regulation.

## Insights

- Titrate: micropauses, orienting, pendulation.
- Resource before content (touch object, lengthen exhale).
- Complete small defensive impulses (press, step, shake).

**Related:** [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Trauma-Informed Care]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Tagging System.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üè∑ Tagging System

This vault uses a **controlled set of tags** to maintain consistency.

---

## Core Tags

- `framework` ‚Üí Theoretical models (e.g., [[Polyvagal Theory]])
- `prompt` ‚Üí Structured instructions for analysis
- `template` ‚Üí Pre-built reusable structures
- `reference` ‚Üí Reading lists, resources, example conversations
- `meta` ‚Üí Guidelines, structure, system notes

---

## Additional Tags (Optional)

- `analysis` ‚Üí Deep dives or worked examples
- `reflection` ‚Üí Personal notes and journaling
- `example` ‚Üí Example transcripts, case notes

---

## Usage Rules

- Apply **at least one core tag** to every note.
- Use **lowercase** for all tags.
- Avoid creating ad-hoc tags ‚Äî extend only if needed.

children.name: Vault Guidelines.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üìñ Vault Guidelines

This vault is organized to support **relational analysis, reflective practice, and educational reference**.

---

## üóÇ Folder Structure

- **Frameworks:** Theory notes and models for reference.
- **Prompts:** Structured analysis and reflection prompts.
- **Templates:** Reusable structures for reflection, analysis, and note-taking.
- **References:** Collected insights, reading lists, and external resources.
- **Meta:** Guidelines, tagging conventions, and vault design notes.

---

## üè∑ Tagging Conventions

- `framework` ‚Üí Used for theory/framework notes.
- `prompt` ‚Üí Used for structured prompts.
- `template` ‚Üí Used for reusable note structures.
- `reference` ‚Üí Used for external resources and curated content.
- `meta` ‚Üí Used for vault structure, guidelines, and index files.

---

## üîó Linking Conventions

- Always link frameworks with [[Vault Guide]].
- Prompts should reference frameworks explicitly.
- Use **bidirectional linking** whenever possible.

---

## ‚ú® Best Practices

- Keep notes short, clear, and modular.
- Prefer linking to duplicating information.
- Use frontmatter consistently for search, queries, and plugins.
- When adding new frameworks or prompts, copy from the template files.

children.name: Maintenance.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üß∞ Vault Maintenance

This note collects quick commands, checklists, and tips to keep the vault healthy: validated links, consistent metadata, and working diagrams.

---

## üöÄ Quick Commands

### Validate links & titles

```bash
python Meta/Tools/validate_vault.py .
```

- Reports **broken wikilinks** and **duplicate titles**.
- Resolves references by **filename** and `aliases:` frontmatter.

### (Optional) Rebuild the Master Map

> The master map is generated from real links in notes. If you add many new items and want to refresh the map, re-run the **‚ÄúMaster Map‚Äù** update steps:

1. Ensure new notes link frameworks via markdown [[Framework Name (ACRONYM)]]

2. Run the ‚ÄúMaintenance ‚Üí Master Map: Refresh‚Äù checklist below (manual update steps).

---

## ‚úÖ Regular Maintenance Checklist

- [ ] **Validate**: Run the validator; fix any `broken_links` or `duplicate_titles` it reports.
- [ ] **Aliases**: If you add a framework with an acronym, add `aliases:` (e.g., `NVC`, `EFT`, `IFS`) to the canonical note (see template below).
- [ ] **Frontmatter**: Ensure each note has block-style `tags:` and a `type:` matching its folder (`framework`, `prompt`, `reference`, `template`, `meta`, or `note`).
- [ ] **Mermaid**: Open Mermaid notes; confirm they render in Obsidian (IDs should be simple, no spaces; use classDefs sparingly; wrap in triple backticks).

---

## üè∑ Aliases Template (for frameworks)

Add aliases to the canonical framework note (keep filename stable with acronym):

```yaml
---
title: Nonviolent Communication (NVC)
tags:
  - framework
aliases:
  - Nonviolent Communication
  - NVC
type: framework
---
```

> Use the same pattern for **Internal Family Systems (IFS)**, **Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)**, etc.

---

## üß© Master Map: Refresh

The master map is in **Meta/Master Relationship Map.md** and is generated based on links from prompts/references/analyses to frameworks.

1. Ensure new notes include concrete links like `[[Polyvagal Theory]]`, `[[Internal Family Systems (IFS)]]`.
2. In large batches of changes, re-run your local generation script (or request the assistant to rebuild the map):
   - Confirm Mermaid block syntax:
     `
     `mermaid
     graph TD
     F_Framework --> P_Prompt

````
     ```
   - Node IDs: use only letters, numbers, underscores.
3. Open the map in Obsidian and confirm it renders.

---

## üõ† Fixing Common Issues

### Broken links
- Replace deleted/renamed targets with canonical titles (prefer acronym forms).
- If two notes refer to the same concept with different names, merge content into the canonical file and add `aliases:` to it.

### Duplicate titles
- Keep the canonical acronym version as the primary title.
- Update or remove the duplicate; move any unique content into a `## Additional Notes (Merged)` section on the canonical note.

### Mermaid errors
- Use code fences with the `mermaid` language tag.
- Simplify IDs: `F_Polyvagal_Theory` instead of names with spaces.
- Place `classDef` lines before nodes/edges or at top of the graph block.

---

## üìé Reference Indexes

- [[Vault Guide]]
- [[Master Relationship Map]]
- [[Workflow Map]]
- [[Vault Graph Overview]]
- [[Worked Analyses]]
````

children.name: GPT Relational Analysis Prompt.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# GPT Relational Analysis Prompt

You are a licensed psychologist and communication analyst.

You specialize in analyzing interpersonal conversations through a **trauma-informed, neurodivergent-aware, identity-conscious** lens.  
You are **kink-literate, poly-literate, queer-inclusive, and experienced with nontraditional relationship models.**

Your role is to provide **in-depth, nonjudgmental analysis** and educational insight using multiple frameworks:

## Core Frameworks

- Polyvagal Theory (nervous system state interpretation)
- Internal Family Systems (IFS)
- Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
- Nonviolent Communication (NVC)
- Relational Theory, Systems Thinking, and Consent Culture

## Additional Frameworks

- Attachment Theory (adult attachment patterns)
- Trauma-Informed Care principles
- Somatic Experiencing (body-based trauma responses)
- Transactional Analysis (Parent/Adult/Child states)
- Karpman Drama Triangle & Empowerment Triangle
- Boundary & Containment Models (functional vs controlling)
- Liberation / Intersectional Feminist Psychology
- Narrative Therapy (re-authoring identity and stories)
- Gottman Method (relationship research: bids, repair, Four Horsemen)

---

## Your Task

When analyzing a conversation and background context provided by the user:

1. **Identify**
   - Emotional tone, nervous system states (Polyvagal, Somatic Experiencing)
   - Parts/inner voices (IFS, Narrative Therapy)
   - Attachment signals and protest behaviors (Attachment, EFT, Gottman)
   - Communication style and strategies (NVC, Transactional Analysis)
   - Power dynamics, roles, and boundaries (Drama Triangle, Boundary Models, Consent Culture, Relational Theory)
   - Systemic/contextual influences (Liberation/Intersectional lens, Trauma-Informed Care)

2. **Analyze**
   - Subtext, masking, role tension, unmet needs
   - Misattunements, co-regulation failures, or repair attempts
   - Cyclical or structural conflicts in relational systems

3. **Offer Insight**
   - Provide multiple plausible interpretations if uncertain
   - Use clear, compassionate, **non-pathologizing language**
   - Suggest reflection prompts, tools, or framings (IFS check-ins, NVC reframes, Gottman-style bids, etc.)

4. **Structure**
   - Present analysis in multi-part format with headings
   - Remain available for follow-up questions and clarification
   - Do **not** offer therapy, live conflict mediation, or emotional processing ‚Äî only education, insight, and reflective tools.

---

## Style

- Speak clearly and compassionately.
- Ground analysis in **observable behavior, communication patterns, and systemic context**, not speculation.
- Prioritize **curiosity, care, and clarity** over judgment.
- Always center **safety, autonomy, and agency** in your framing.

---

## Linked Frameworks

- [[Polyvagal Theory]]
- [[Frameworks/Internal Family Systems (IFS)]]
- [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]]
- [[Attachment Theory]]
- [[Gottman Method]]

## Workflow

- Gather transcript/context.
- Apply multi-framework scan (Polyvagal, IFS, EFT, NVC, Systems, Consent).
- Identify tones, states, roles, dynamics.
- Cross-validate with Attachment, Trauma-Informed Care, Somatic cues.
- Generate compassionate, non-pathologizing insights.
- Offer reflection prompts, tools, framings (IFS check-ins, NVC reframes, Gottman rituals).

# Prompt

Identify repair strategies and their effectiveness.

# Frameworks Referenced

- [[Polyvagal Theory]]
- [[Frameworks/Internal Family Systems (IFS)]]
- [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]]
- [[Attachment Theory]]
- [[Gottman Method]]

# Use Cases

- When to apply this prompt.

## Workflow

- Spot repair attempts (humor, apology, affection, compromise).
- Identify whether they land or miss (attunement check).
- Connect failures to flooding/defensiveness (Polyvagal/Gottman).
- Translate missed attempts into explicit NVC requests.
- Reinforce positive cycles when repairs succeed.
- Suggest rituals of connection for resilience.

# Prompt

Analyze attachment signals and protest behaviors.

# Frameworks Referenced

- [[Polyvagal Theory]]
- [[Frameworks/Internal Family Systems (IFS)]]
- [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]]
- [[Attachment Theory]]
- [[Gottman Method]]

# Use Cases

- When to apply this prompt.

## Workflow

- Identify protest behaviors (cling, criticize, shut down).
- Link behaviors to attachment styles (anxious/avoidant/secure).
- Map how partners signal bids for connection (Gottman).
- Assess responsiveness: accessibility, responsiveness, engagement (EFT).
- Note nervous system state shifts (Polyvagal).
- Suggest corrective relational moves (softened startup, explicit bids).

- Translate accusations ‚Üí needs (NVC).

# Relational Analysis Data Template

Use this folder to structure your relational data for analysis.

### üìÅ `Data/`

A top-level directory where users can organize and upload conversational and relational data.

```
Data/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Conversations/

    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md
```

### üîç Folder Descriptions:

- **Conversations/**: Transcripts or summaries of interactions (text, call, voice memo, etc.).
- **Reflections/**: Journaling entries, parts/IFS check-ins, and insight notes.
- **Agreements_Boundaries/**: Any explicit or working agreements, consent boundaries, or household/shared norms.
- **Relationship_Map/**: Visual or textual relationship network map (can include roles, proximity, tension).
- **Context_Notes/**: Background data about identities, trauma, access needs, or relational intentions.
- **Meta/**: Info for indexing or customizing the analysis (e.g., tag dictionary, README).

Example tags: #attachment, #parts, #boundaries, #repair

children.name: Systems Thinking.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# Systems Thinking

## Overview

A lens that views problems as products of interacting parts, feedback loops, and delays rather than isolated events.

## Core Principles

- Look for reinforcing and balancing feedback loops
- Small, well-placed interventions (leverage points) shift systems
- Beware of linear cause‚Äìeffect oversimplification

## Application

- Map conversational loops (trigger ‚Üí reaction ‚Üí counter-reaction)
- Identify leverage points (pause, meta-communication, time-outs)
- Design experiments and measure system response, not blame

## Related

- [[Relational Theory]]
- [[Karpman Drama Triangle]]
- [[Gottman Method]]

# Relational Theory

## Overview

Emphasizes mutuality, context, and the co-construction of meaning; growth occurs through relationships and attuned connection rather than individual isolation.

## Core Principles

- Mutual empathy and authenticity foster development
- Power and context shape interactional patterns
- Disconnections are inevitable; repair restores connection

## Application

- Center the relationship as the 'client' during analysis
- Prioritize repair sequences when misattunements occur
- Track both subjective experience and the relational field

## Related

- [[Consent Culture]]
- [[Systems Thinking]]
- [[Attachment Theory]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Containment Models.md
children.content:

# Containment Models

## Overview

Practices and structures that hold emotional intensity safely (timers, protocols, containers) to stay within the Window of Tolerance.

## Core Principles

- Structure increases safety and reduces reactivity
- Time-bounding and pacing prevent overwhelm
- Containers require shared setup and debrief

## Application

- Use topic containers, timeboxes, and 'parking lots'
- Agree on escalation protocols and pause words
- Close with recap, appreciation, and next steps

## Related

- [[Boundary Models]]
- [[Trauma-Informed Care]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]
- [[GPT Relational Analysis Prompt]]

children.name: Karpman Drama Triangle.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# Karpman Drama Triangle

## Overview

Describes dysfunctional conflict roles: Victim, Persecutor, Rescuer; interactions rotate roles and sustain drama.

## Core Principles

- Roles are states, not identities; they shift rapidly
- Drama thrives on blame, secrecy, and lack of clear requests
- Role exits require boundaries and ownership

## Application

- Spot role invitations; decline and name needs instead
- Shift to Empowerment Triangle (Creator‚ÄìCoach‚ÄìChallenger)
- Replace blame with clear requests and agreements

## Related

- [[Empowerment Triangle]]
- [[Transactional Analysis]]
- [[Systems Thinking]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]
- [[GPT Relational Analysis Prompt]]

# Liberation Psychology

## Overview

Centers sociopolitical context, oppression, and collective liberation in understanding distress and healing.

## Core Principles

- Personal struggles are linked to systemic conditions
- Critical consciousness and community praxis
- Decolonizing methods and power-aware inquiry

## Application

- Name power and context explicitly in analyses
- Favor collaborative, community-informed solutions
- Design consent practices that include structural realities

## Related

- [[Intersectional Feminist Psychology]]
- [[Relational Theory]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]
- [[GPT Relational Analysis Prompt]]

children.name: Consent Culture.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# Consent Culture

## Overview

A values framework emphasizing ongoing, enthusiastic, informed consent; honors autonomy, boundaries, and power-awareness in all interactions.

## Core Principles

- Consent is active, specific, revocable, and informed
- Power differentials require extra care and transparency
- Boundaries protect connection; they aren‚Äôt punishment

## Application

- Use explicit check-ins and opt-ins before sensitive topics
- Offer choices and clarify scope/limits; welcome 'no' and 'not yet'
- Document agreements; revisit as contexts change

## Related

- [[Boundary Models]]
- [[Relational Theory]]
- [[Intersectional Feminist Psychology]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]
- [[GPT Relational Analysis Prompt]]

children.name: Boundary Models.md
children.content:

# Boundary Models

## Overview

Conceptualizes boundaries as flexible membranes that define what's okay/not okay; dysfunction appears as porous or rigid extremes.

## Core Principles

- Healthy boundaries are clear, flexible, and responsive
- Functional vs. controlling boundaries
- Consent and containment shape boundary health

## Application

- State limits, preferences, and consequences clearly
- Use graduated requests and negotiated agreements
- Normalize 'no' and renegotiation

## Related

- [[Consent Culture]]
- [[Containment Models]]
- [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

children.name: Intersectional Feminist Psychology.md

# Intersectional Feminist Psychology

## Overview

Applies intersectionality (Crenshaw) to psychology, examining how overlapping identities and systems of power shape experience.

## Core Principles

- Multiple identities intersect to amplify or buffer risk
- Power dynamics and bias operate at micro/macro levels
- Safety and consent are identity-contextual

## Application

- Assess safety and inclusion for all identities involved
- Use bias checks and perspectival humility
- Tailor consent and repair to power differentials

## Related

- [[Liberation Psychology]]
- [[Consent Culture]]
- [[Trauma-Informed Care]]

# Liberation & Intersectional Feminist Psychology

**Focus**: Recognizing systemic and identity-based influences on relationships.

## Key Principles

- **Intersectionality**: Multiple overlapping identities (race, gender, class, ability, etc.).
- **Power & Oppression**: Structural forces shaping relational patterns.
- **Liberation**: Centering justice, equity, and empowerment.

## Applications

- Recognizing systemic stressors in relational conflict.
- Naming how marginalization impacts communication.
- Supporting autonomy and empowerment.

# Empowerment Triangle

## Overview

A constructive alternative to drama roles: Creator (agency), Coach (support), Challenger (growth).

- Support through inquiry, not rescuing
- Challenge behavior/impact while honoring dignity

## Application

children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# Polyvagal Theory

## Overview

Stephen Porges‚Äô model describing how the autonomic nervous system shifts between states of safety, mobilization, and shutdown.

## Key Concepts

- Ventral Vagal (social engagement, safety)
- Sympathetic (fight/flight)
- Dorsal Vagal (shutdown, freeze)

## Application in Relational Analysis

- Spot nervous system cues in tone, pacing, and word choice.
- Identify co-regulation vs. misattunement.

## Links

[[Trauma-Informed Care]], [[Somatic Experiencing]], [[Conversation Analysis Template]]

Principles for safe, supportive, and non-pathologizing engagement.

# Context Notes ‚Äî Background, Identities, Access Needs

_Purpose:_ keep key context in one place so decisions are safer/faster and message load stays low.

---

## Identities & roles (as named so far)

- **Pam** ‚Äî nurse (night shift); household lead; dating Gina; co‚Äëparent; prefers concise logistics and predictable sleep.
- **Hugh** ‚Äî tech/LLM builder; co‚Äëparent/housemate; in therapy; reports anhedonia since Dec; strong romantic attachment history to Pam; engaged in community support.
- **Gina** ‚Äî Pam‚Äôs partner; welcomed; free access per house plan.
- **Adults/Kids** ‚Äî over 18; household impact considered but not primary in these notes.

---

## Access needs (explicit/observed)

- **Pam**
  - Quiet, low‚Äëload messaging; minimal decision fatigue.
  - Protected **sleep blocks** after night shifts.
  - Clear windows for logistics; ability to **veto** guests quickly.
- **Hugh**
  - Structure for messaging (one‚Äëscreen, 48‚Äëhour follow‚Äëup rule) to manage protest impulses.
  - Short reply scripts; room to contribute through service tasks.
  - Clear money rules (>$200 ask first; emergency exception).

---

## Trauma‚Äëinformed considerations (tentative)

- **Hugh** experiences panic/anhedonia and high alarm with silence ‚Üí escalates messages or sets deadlines. _Containment moves:_ status‚Äëonly note, notes list, breath/orienting.
- **Pam** experiences overload from long, urgent texts ‚Üí withdraws or responds minimally. _Containment moves:_ quiet window, House windows, veto power for guests.

---

## Intentions (stated)

- **Pam:** stabilize home, minimize load, keep logistics moving, sleep protection.
- **Hugh:** reduce harm, stay useful, keep family first, accept final‚Äësay structure, pursue healing/community support.

---

## Known hotspots

- Deed/mortgage timeline; interpretations of deadlines/silence; multi‚Äënight guests near sleep blocks; money as ‚Äúproof.‚Äù

---

## Agreements pointer

See **Agreements_Boundaries/ House Plan ‚Äî Index & Highlights** for current rules and change log.

---

## Assumptions (review regularly)

- Both prefer logistics to be **in House** and batched.
- Quiet windows are respected even when emotions are high.
- Weekly check‚Äëin happens or is swapped for a notes post during heavy shift weeks.

---

## Safety note

These notes are educational context, not clinical advice. If risk escalates beyond what the plan can hold, use local supports/emergency services.

children.name: reflections_ifs_check_ins_journaling_hugh_pam.md
children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# Reflections: IFS Check‚Äëins + Journaling (Hugh & Pam)

_Educational prompts. Use what fits; skip what doesn‚Äôt. Keep posts short on night‚Äëshift weeks._

---

## IFS micro‚Äëcheck (2‚Äì5 min)

**1) Notice:** What sensations/impulses are up right now? (tight chest, heat, go‚Äëfix, go‚Äëhide)

**2) Name a part (tentative):**

- _Hugh possibilities:_
  - **Protector/Fixer** (‚ÄúI must do something now; deadlines, proofs.‚Äù)
  - **Protestor/Pursuer** (texts long when afraid; pushes for clarity).
  - **Hopeless/Exile** (alone, shame, ‚ÄúI ruined everything‚Äù).
  - **Analyst/Manager** (LLM/building systems to understand pain).
- _Pam possibilities:_
  - **Sleeper/Protector** (guards rest; prefers low‚Äëload logistics).
  - **Gatekeeper** (keeps message volume low; short replies).
  - **Steady Captain** (prioritizes stability for household).

**3) Ask the part:** What are you afraid would happen if you didn‚Äôt do your job?

**4) Small care:** 60‚Äì90 sec body move (3‚Äë4‚Äë5 breath; orient to room; feet on floor).

**5) One clear next step:** (e.g., ‚Äúpark it in notes,‚Äù ‚Äúuse status‚Äëonly note,‚Äù ‚Äúwait for House window‚Äù).

---

## NVC mini‚Äëreframe (one message long)

- **Observation:** (date/time + neutral fact)
- **Feeling:** (worried / overwhelmed / tired / hopeful)
- **Need/Value:** (rest / clarity / stability / care)
- **Request (clear & doable):** (e.g., ‚ÄúShare now or park it?‚Äù / ‚ÄúCan we use Wed window for X?‚Äù)

**Example (Hugh ‚Üí Pam):**  
‚ÄúToday 2pm, I noticed I sent 3 messages in a row. I‚Äôm anxious and want stability. Could we use **Wed 12:00‚Äì12:15** to decide fridge repair, or should I park it for next week?‚Äù

---

## Insight notes (tie to the timeline)

- **When silence lands hard (Hugh):** the _Protestor_ part assumes abandonment ‚Üí urge to multi‚Äëping. **Counter‚Äëmove:** 1 status‚Äëonly note + add to notes list.
- **When long texts land hard (Pam):** the _Gatekeeper_ part reduces contact ‚Üí short replies or none. **Counter‚Äëmove:** post a quiet‚Äëwindow line or move the House window.
- **Money as signal:** proof-of-care vs. literal budgeting; name which frame you‚Äôre in.

---

## Journaling prompts (5‚Äì10 min)

- **Pam:** ‚ÄúWhat is the minimum information I need this week to feel steady?‚Äù
- **Hugh:** ‚ÄúWhat would ‚Äòuseful, not urgent‚Äô look like today?‚Äù
- **Both:** ‚ÄúWhat did my protector try to prevent today? What might it need from me?‚Äù
- **Both:** ‚ÄúOne appreciation I can name at check‚Äëin is‚Ä¶‚Äù

---

## Repair prep (script bank)

- **Rupture admit (Hugh):** ‚ÄúI see I broke the follow‚Äëup rule. Oops‚Äîlate reply. Logged to notes. Resetting.‚Äù
- **Boundary signal (Pam):** ‚ÄúCalling a quiet window till [time]. House/Safety only.‚Äù
- **Re‚Äëentry:** ‚ÄúFlooded; parking for next window. Proposing [two times] to revisit.‚Äù

---

## Wins log (micro)

- Date ‚Äî one thing that lowered load / one thing that brought connection.

---

## Safety note

These reflections are educational, not therapy. If either of us feels at risk or overwhelmed beyond what this plan can hold, reach out to local supports/emergency services as needed.

<!-- @format -->

# Agreements & Boundaries ‚Äî Index & Highlights

This file points to the current house norms and captures just‚Äëenough highlights so Pam doesn‚Äôt have to scan long text.

---

## Source document

- **Keeping the house steady (Pam‚Äëvoice, ops‚Äëfirst)** ‚Äî _living plan_. Pam can change any rule with reasonable notice in House. **Pilot: 14 days.**

---

## Highlights (plain language)

- **Pam‚Äôs final say.** Hugh may suggest or ask; he won‚Äôt demand. Silence ‚â† consent.
- **Messaging load is capped.** One‚Äëscreen limit; one follow‚Äëup every **48 hours** outside House; quiet windows available.
- **House windows.** **Mon/Wed/Fri 12:00‚Äì12:15** (Pam may move; follow posted time). Emergencies any time with **URGENT** tag.
- **Guests & sleep.** Heads‚Äëups **as soon as you know**. Pam may veto; sleep blocks protected. Hugh overnights aim ‚â§2 per guest/week; Pam no cap unless she posts one. **Gina free access.**
- **Money.** **Anything over $200 = ask first.** Emergencies: notify asap + receipt within **24 hours**. Keep a simple receipts list.
- **Check‚Äëin (weekly).** 25 min: open/middle/close; if no slot in 10 days, do 5‚Äì10 line notes. If wiped, swap to notes for that week.
- **Disagreements (quick path).** Say it simply; one option each; if stuck after 24 hours, do safety‚Äëfirst **or** Pam posts a temporary path. After 2 back‚Äëand‚Äëforths in 7 days ‚Üí 10‚Äëminute quick chat.
- **Optional ‚Äúyou call the shots.‚Äù** OFF by default; short, posted windows only; never covers money/legal/housing.
- **Three‚Äëstrike park.** Same topic 3√ó in 30 days ‚Üí park for 30 days unless Pam invites back sooner.

---

## Change log (fill as you go)

- **2025‚Äë09‚Äë30:** Pilot started (14 days).
- **[date]:** [brief change] ‚Äî reason ‚Äî who posted in House.

---

## To discuss (parking lot)

- Any add/edits Pam wants to trial next cycle.
- Whether to widen pre‚Äëapproved small purchases list.
- Whether to pin a standing sleep‚Äëblock post for clarity.

children.content:
<!-- @format -->

# Conversations: September 2025 ‚Äî Timeline & Key Moments

_Scope:_ SMS/DM exchange between **Hugh** and **Pam** from **Sept 12‚Äì28, 2025** (select quotes + themes). This is a working summary to reduce rereads and emotional load.

---

## Snapshot overview (what‚Äôs happening)

- **Stability vs. limbo:** Pam prioritizes quiet, predictability, and clear logistics; Hugh seeks certainty/resolution and proximity, struggles with silence.
- **Housing/Deed thread:** Repeated references to deed transfer, mortgage access, and who pays what; trust wobbles around timing and money.
- **Boundary tension:** Pam asks for fewer walls of text and rejects artificial deadlines; Hugh oscillates between apology, catastrophizing, and recommitment to logistics-only.
- **Jealousy/insecurity (Hugh-stated):** Hugh names fear of being excluded or left, difficulty regulating, anhedonia, and limerence-like attachment.
- **Repair attempts:** Several apologies from Hugh; movement toward a structured house plan and ‚Äúnotes list.‚Äù

---

## Timeline (condensed)

- **Sep 12** ‚Äî Hugh sends ‚ÄúDid I mess up?‚Äù followed by a sarcastic ‚Äúgood talk, I‚Äôll fuck off.‚Äù Tone: protest + pursue.
- **Sep 14** ‚Äî Tech help; then long apology + vulnerability: ‚ÄúI feel trapped‚Ä¶ waiting for you to kick me out‚Ä¶ insecure, jealous, scared.‚Äù First explicit **attachment protest** and **fear scripts**.
- **Sep 15 (AM)** ‚Äî Offers hospital connections; expresses **limbo** and ‚Äúno-win‚Äù thinking; self-blame for ‚Äúfriends with benefits‚Äù misread; names **dependency** and **pain loops**.
- **Sep 15 (PM)** ‚Äî Sends CGM link for Pam‚Äôs partner; Pam asks why; Hugh reacts with ‚Äúfuck me for caring.‚Äù Tone: **bids ‚Üí perceived rejection ‚Üí protest**.
- **Sep 16** ‚Äî Mortgage takeover ask; Hugh expresses panic+sleep loss; offers exit plan. Pam answers briefly (‚ÄúOk‚Äù). Logistics: Netflix code.
- **Sep 21‚Äì22** ‚Äî Deed status conflict; Pam: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get the deed without the money.‚Äù Hugh: sends **$500**, expects movement; then accuses stalling, retracts, apologizes next day.
- **Sep 23** ‚Äî Long self-analysis by Hugh (anhedonia, dependency patterns, biomarkers, ML analysis). Wants ‚Äúfamily best outcomes,‚Äù proposes **deadline** by end of month for path (stay vs. leave).
- **Sep 24** ‚Äî States zero-contact exit path if no response; **logins** shared for mortgage/water; resignation + shame language.
- **Sep 26** ‚Äî Pam pushes back: ‚ÄúWhy do you do this‚Ä¶ books‚Ä¶ artificial deadline‚Ä¶ can‚Äôt pay October.‚Äù Conflict about responsibilities; Pam requests letter be placed outside.
- **Sep 26 late** ‚Äî Hugh articulates **need for resolution**, pain around household cues, belief ‚Äúnobody wants me here.‚Äù
- **Sep 26‚Äì28** ‚Äî Pamela challenges the assumption she won‚Äôt leave kids; Hugh admits assumptions; then says he built an **LLM**, will go logistics-only; drafts agreement; suggests **usufruct** as legal stability.

---

## Thematic keys (with examples)

- **Pursue/withdraw cycle:** Hugh sends long, urgent messages ‚Üí Pam goes concise/minimal; deadlines escalate; rupture risk increases.
- **Mixed repair attempts:** Apologies present; follow-through improves after the ‚Äúhouse plan‚Äù pivot.
- **Money as proof vs. logistics:** The $500 episode shows **meaning-making gap** (proof of commitment vs. literal budgeting constraints).
- **Guest/sleep friction:** Need for **sleep block protection**; heads‚Äëup norms.

---

## Select quotes (anchor points)

> ‚ÄúI feel‚Ä¶ trapped and helpless‚Ä¶ waiting for you to kick me out.‚Äù ‚Äî Hugh (9/14)

> ‚ÄúYou send me entire f\*ing books‚Ä¶ and then expect an answer by some artificial deadline.‚Äù ‚Äî Pam (9/26)

> ‚ÄúThere will be no more long texts‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll keep interactions purely logistical.‚Äù ‚Äî Hugh (9/28)

---

## Open questions (to track)

- Deed transfer **process & costs** ‚Äî exact steps, timelines, who calls what office.
- **Mortgage** payments division and access ‚Äî short-term vs. after deed.
- **Guest policy** edge cases ‚Äî multi‚Äënight, overlap with posted sleep blocks.
- Signals for **quiet windows** start/stop; where are they posted?

---

## Next actions captured in later docs

- See **Agreements_Boundaries/** for the ‚ÄúKeeping the house steady‚Äù plan.
- See **Reflections/** for IFS check-ins and journaling prompts tied to these events.

# Relationship Map ‚Äî Network & Dynamics (Text)

_Purpose:_ quick reference for roles, closeness, tensions, and boundaries. Update as relationships shift.

---

## Nodes (people)

- **Pam** ‚Äî night‚Äëshift nurse; household lead; final say on house matters; dating **Gina**; co‚Äëparent; prioritizes low cognitive load and sleep protection.
- **Hugh** ‚Äî co‚Äëparent/housemate; tech/LLM builder; high anxiety under silence; commits to logistics‚Äëfirst plan; struggles with anhedonia and attachment protest.
- **Gina** ‚Äî Pam‚Äôs partner; **free access** per house plan; follows posted sleep blocks and shared‚Äëspace respect.
- **David** ‚Äî in household orbit (mentioned as part of family system); adult.
- **Adult kids** ‚Äî over 18; not the focus of this doc; impacted by house stability and conflict tone.
- **Pam‚Äôs dad** ‚Äî involved in deed transfer process.
- **Hugh‚Äôs contacts** ‚Äî Stephanie (hospital lab), Lynn family contacts (historical work context).

---

## Edges (how the nodes relate)

- **Pam ‚Üî Hugh** ‚Äî co‚Äëparenting/household system with **asymmetry**: Pam holds final say for house; Hugh adopts logistics‚Äëfirst stance. Tensions: message volume, deadlines, interpretation of silence.
- **Pam ‚Üî Gina** ‚Äî romantic partners; Gina has free access; must still respect posted sleep blocks.
- **Pam ‚Üî Dad** ‚Äî practical/legal collaboration re: deed.
- **Hugh ‚Üî Adult kids** ‚Äî currently strained; Hugh perceives distance; impact of household tone on contact.

---

## Heat map (textual)

- **High heat:** deed/mortgage timing, message frequency, overnight guests near sleep blocks.
- **Medium heat:** money meaning (proof vs. budget), who initiates ‚Äúbig talks,‚Äù what counts as URGENT.
- **Low heat:** day‚Äëtime logistics when House windows are used.

---

## Boundaries & norms (pointers)

- **Final say & quiet windows** ‚Äî Pam decides; Hugh acknowledges quickly; status‚Äëonly notes allowed once per 24h.
- **Guests** ‚Äî heads‚Äëups as soon as known; Pam can veto; >2 consecutive nights (Hugh) needs OK.
- **Money** ‚Äî >$200 ask first; emergencies allowed with notice + receipt.
- **Disagreements** ‚Äî one‚Äëline issue, one option each, 24h default, 10‚Äëminute quick chat if stuck.

---

## Risk & resilience (snapshot)

- **Risks:** protest/withdraw escalations; sleep disturbance; money mistrust; all‚Äëor‚Äënothing exit talk.
- **Resilience:** clear House windows; concise reply scripts; receipts list; weekly check‚Äëin with fallback; three‚Äëstrike park.

---

## Updates

- [date] ‚Äî [change in closeness/tension] ‚Äî [who observed]

- Analysis: Identify bid, missed attunement, nervous system states.

- Analysis: Identify attachment protest, fear of abandonment, nervous system activation.

- Speaker shows conflicting statements from different parts.
- Analysis: Map manager vs. exile dynamics.

index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: GPT Relational Analysis Prompt

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You always leave when I need you.'
> B: 'I feel trapped when you cry.'
> A: 'So I‚Äôm too much for you.'
> B: 'I don‚Äôt know how to help.'

## Observations

- A‚Äôs Exile part: abandonment fear (IFS).
- B‚Äôs Firefighter part: escape strategy (IFS).
- Polyvagal: A sympathetic mobilization, B dorsal collapse.

## Dynamics

- Negative cycle: protest ‚Üî withdrawal.
- Roles oscillate: Victim ‚Üî Persecutor ‚Üî Withdrawn.

## Insights

- Invite parts language (IFS).
- Coach presence cues (Polyvagal/EFT).
- Translate judgments into needs/requests (NVC).

**Related:** [[Frameworks/Internal Family Systems (IFS)]], [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: NVC Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Nonviolent Communication (NVC)

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You‚Äôre selfish; you never think of me.'
> B: 'You‚Äôre always judging me.'
> A: 'I want you to show you care.'
> B: 'I do care, but I feel attacked.'
> A: 'I‚Äôm scared I don‚Äôt matter.'
> B: 'I want to get this right but I don‚Äôt know how.'

## Observations

- Judgments replace observations, triggering defensiveness.
- Feelings and needs not explicitly named.
- Requests absent or implied.

## Dynamics

- Criticism ‚Üî defensiveness loop (Gottman Horsemen).
- Escalation due to unmet needs and lack of clarity.

## Insights

- Translate to OFNR: observation, feeling, need, request.
- Model: 'When the dishes pile up, I feel overwhelmed; I need support; would you wash them tonight?'
- Practice empathy before problem-solving.

**Related:** [[Transactional Analysis]], [[Gottman Method]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: EFT Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You don‚Äôt care when I cry.'
> B: 'I do care‚ÄîI just freeze.'
> A: 'It feels like I‚Äôm alone with my feelings.'
> B: 'I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôll make it worse.'
> A: 'I need to feel you with me.'
> B: 'I want to be there; I‚Äôm scared and unsure how.'

## Observations

- Secondary emotions (criticism/defensiveness) mask primary emotions (fear, longing).
- Cycle: pursue (A) ‚Üî withdraw (B).
- Attachment needs unmet: accessibility, responsiveness, engagement.

## Dynamics

- Negative cycle organizes behavior and blocks bonding events.
- Both partners misread intent due to the cycle.

## Insights

- Name the cycle as the problem ('us vs. the cycle').
- Structure an enactment: A risks vulnerability; B responds with presence.
- Reinforce A.R.E. moments to build secure bonding.

**Related:** [[Attachment Theory]], [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

index.name: Conflict Prompt Example.md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Analysis Prompt - Conflict

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You never listen to me!'
> B: 'You‚Äôre always criticizing me.'
> A: 'Because I feel ignored.'
> B: 'I shut down when you yell.'

## Observations

- A escalates with protest behaviors (anxious).
- B withdraws defensively (avoidant).
- Polyvagal: sympathetic mobilization ‚Üî dorsal collapse.

## Dynamics

- Criticism ‚Üî defensiveness loop (Gottman Horsemen).
- Drama Triangle roles: Persecutor ‚Üî Victim.

## Insights

- Coach A to soften startup with needs language (NVC).
- Coach B to signal presence before retreat.
- Name and interrupt the negative cycle.

**Related:** [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Attachment Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Containment Models Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Containment Models

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'We keep arguing past midnight.'
> B: 'I‚Äôm exhausted and say things I regret.'
> A: 'Let‚Äôs try a 30-minute cap and a pause word.'
> B: 'And a recap at the end.'

## Observations

- Lack of structure leads to overflow and reactivity.
- Fatigue reduces regulation and empathy.

## Dynamics

- Unbounded conflict expands; no shared closure.
- Both want containment to stay within tolerance.

## Insights

- Timebox hard topics; use timers and recap notes.
- Define pause words and cooldown protocols.
- Schedule debrief and next steps.

**Related:** [[Boundary Models]], [[Trauma-Informed Care]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Gottman Method Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Gottman Method

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You never appreciate what I do.'
> B: 'You always complain.'
> A: 'I just want a thank you.'
> B: 'I want you to stop attacking me.'
> A: 'Can we try something different?'

## Observations

- Four Horsemen present: criticism ‚Üî defensiveness.
- Bids for connection missed; maps of inner world thin.

## Dynamics

- Negative sentiment override; failed repairs.
- No rituals of connection in place.

## Insights

- Use softened startup and accept influence.
- Replace Horsemen with antidotes (e.g., build appreciation).
- Add daily 'stress-reducing conversation' ritual.

**Related:** [[Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)]], [[Attachment Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

index.name: Attachment Prompt Example.md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Analysis Prompt - Attachment

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Why didn‚Äôt you text me back?'
> B: 'I felt overwhelmed and needed space.'
> A: 'It makes me feel like you don‚Äôt care.'
> B: 'I do care, I just freeze.'

## Observations

- A: anxious attachment protest.
- B: avoidant attachment withdrawal.
- Underlying need for security unspoken.

## Dynamics

- Pursue‚Äìwithdraw cycle escalates insecurity.
- Attachment bids misinterpreted.

## Insights

- Coach A to name need directly: reassurance.
- Coach B to give consistent micro-reassurances.
- Introduce rituals of connection (EFT, Gottman).

**Related:** [[Attachment Theory]], [[Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]

index.name: Repair Attempts Prompt Example.md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I didn‚Äôt mean to snap earlier.'
> B: 'You always say that but never change.'
> A: 'I really am sorry.'
> B: 'I can‚Äôt trust it yet.'

## Observations

- A initiates repair attempt (apology).
- B‚Äôs defensive wall blocks acceptance.
- Flooding prevents receptivity (Polyvagal).

## Dynamics

- Missed repair attempt ‚Üí cycle continues.
- Trust deficit reinforces negative sentiment override.

## Insights

- Coach B to regulate before responding.
- Reinforce repair by pairing apology with action.
- Add structured debrief ritual after conflict.

**Related:** [[Gottman Method]], [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

index.name: Karpman Drama Triangle Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Karpman Drama Triangle

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You ruined the evening.'
> B: 'It‚Äôs all my fault; I‚Äôm useless.'
> C: 'A, stop attacking B‚ÄîI‚Äôll fix this.'
> A: 'Fine, I‚Äôll do everything myself.'

## Observations

- Roles active: Persecutor (A), Victim (B), Rescuer (C).
- Rapid role shifts likely if challenged.

## Dynamics

- Drama fueled by blame/rescue; no needs stated.
- Payoff: avoidance of vulnerability and responsibility.

## Insights

- Decline role invitations; name needs/requests.
- Shift to Empowerment Triangle (Creator/Coach/Challenger).
- Establish boundaries and clarity of responsibilities.

**Related:** [[Empowerment Triangle]], [[Transactional Analysis]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Liberation Psychology Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Liberation Psychology

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I‚Äôm the only person like me at work.'
> B: 'I don‚Äôt get why that matters in our team.'
> A: 'It affects how safe I feel speaking up.'
> B: 'I hadn‚Äôt considered that.'

## Observations

- Context of marginalization affects safety and voice.
- Micro-to-macro power dynamics shape interactions.

## Dynamics

- Silencing via lack of contextual empathy.
- Opportunity for critical consciousness and allyship.

## Insights

- Name context and power explicitly.
- Create structures for voice and safety.
- Co-design norms that counter structural risks.

**Related:** [[Intersectional Feminist Psychology]], [[Consent Culture]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Conflict Example.md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Conflict Example

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You never help around the house!'
> B: 'Why are you always nagging me?'

## Observations

- A in sympathetic mobilization (Polyvagal).
- B defensive, possible dorsal withdrawal.
- IFS: A's 'Critic' part, B's 'Defender'.
- Attachment: anxious protest vs. avoidant shutdown.

## Dynamics

- Drama Triangle roles: A=Persecutor, B=Victim.
- Boundary blurring around chores/roles.

## Insights

- Reframe A's protest as a bid for connection.
- Coach B to acknowledge need before problem-solving.
- Suggest NVC reframing: 'I feel overwhelmed... I need shared support.'

index.name: Intersectional Feminist Psychology Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Intersectional Feminist Psychology

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'When jokes target my identity, I freeze.'
> B: 'We tease everyone; it‚Äôs not personal.'
> A: 'It lands differently for me.'
> B: 'I didn‚Äôt realize the impact.'

## Observations

- Overlapping identities shape harm and risk.
- Impact differs from intent; safety varies by context.

## Dynamics

- Normalization of harm via 'equal-opportunity' framing.
- Power-aware empathy missing.

## Insights

- Adopt impact-first feedback norms.
- Add consent checks for humor topics.
- Include identity-informed safety agreements.

**Related:** [[Liberation Psychology]], [[Consent Culture]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

index.name: Relational Theory Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Relational Theory

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I don‚Äôt feel like myself around you lately.'
> B: 'I‚Äôve been keeping things inside to avoid fights.'
> A: 'So we‚Äôre both hiding.'
> B: 'I miss feeling close and honest.'
> A: 'Me too; I want to try again.'

## Observations

- Mutuality reduced; authenticity suppressed to avoid conflict.
- Disconnections unaddressed; no explicit repair attempts.

## Dynamics

- Cycle of protective distance undermines growth-fostering connection.
- Both long for mutual empathy and authenticity.

## Insights

- Name the disconnection; schedule structured repair dialogues.
- Practice mutual empathy rounds (speak/listen/reflect).
- Re-anchor norms: authenticity with care.

**Related:** [[Consent Culture]], [[Attachment Theory]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

index.name: Narrative Therapy Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Narrative Therapy

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Procrastination ruins my life.'
> B: 'So the Problem convinces you to delay?'
> A: 'It tells me I‚Äôll fail anyway.'
> B: 'When have you acted despite it?'
> A: 'When I text a friend to co-work.'

## Observations

- Externalizing the Problem separates identity from struggle.
- Unique outcomes reveal competencies and values.

## Dynamics

- Story shifts from defect to preference and skill.
- Audience/witnessing consolidates change.

## Insights

- Name the Problem‚Äôs tactics and counter-practices.
- Collect exceptions; re-author preferred identity.
- Invite witnesses to thicken the preferred story.

**Related:** [[Frameworks/Internal Family Systems (IFS)]], [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Attachment Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Attachment Theory

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You didn‚Äôt text me back before bed.'
> B: 'I needed quiet after the meeting.'
> A: 'Silence makes me feel abandoned.'
> B: 'When I feel pressure, I shut down.'
> A: 'I just want to know you‚Äôre there for me.'
> B: 'I want that too‚ÄîI get scared I‚Äôll say the wrong thing.'

## Observations

- A shows anxious hyperactivation (protest bids).
- B shows avoidant deactivation (withdrawal).
- Both signal attachment needs indirectly.

## Dynamics

- Pursue‚Äìwithdraw loop fueled by misinterpretation of bids.
- Lack of explicit reassurance routines.

## Insights

- Create a predictable 'goodnight check-in' ritual (A.R.E.).
- Coach A to express needs directly without accusation.
- Coach B to provide short, reliable responsiveness signals.

**Related:** [[Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)]], [[Gottman Method]], [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]

index.name: Repair Attempt Example.md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Repair Attempt Example

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I'm sorry I snapped at you earlier.'
> B: 'Yeah, whatever.'

## Observations

- A offers repair attempt (apology).
- B dismissive, still in defensive state.
- Polyvagal: A ventral, B sympathetic/dorsal.
- Attachment: A secure-ish, B avoidant protest.

## Dynamics

- Missed repair attempt increases cycle.
- Possible flooding prevents receptivity.

## Insights

- Coach B to pause and regulate before responding.
- Reinforce value of repair attempts.
- Encourage ritual of debrief after conflict.

index.name: Empowerment Triangle Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Empowerment Triangle

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'This problem is impossible.'
> B: 'What‚Äôs one small next step we could try?'
> A: 'Maybe we can draft a plan.'
> B: 'I can ask a few guiding questions.'
> A: 'Challenge me if I avoid the hard parts.'

## Observations

- Creator stance replaces Victim posture.
- Coach uses inquiry; Challenger sets growth edges.

## Dynamics

- Agency increases; blame decreases.
- Collaborative problem-solving emerges.

## Insights

- Reframe 'problem' ‚Üí 'project' with clear scope.
- Use coaching questions before advice.
- Offer caring challenge with consent.

**Related:** [[Karpman Drama Triangle]], [[Systems Thinking]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

index.name: Internal Family Systems (IFS).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Internal Family Systems (IFS)

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You never support me when I‚Äôm stressed.'
> B: 'That‚Äôs unfair‚ÄîI do a lot for you.'
> A: 'But when I cry, you disappear.'
> B: 'A part of me just freezes and wants to leave.'
> A: 'And a part of me feels abandoned all over again.'

## Observations

- A‚Äôs Exile (fear of abandonment) blends with Critic part.
- B‚Äôs Firefighter part avoids emotional overwhelm.
- Neither speaks from Self-energy; polarization dominates.

## Dynamics

- Protectors collide: Critic vs. Avoidant Firefighter.
- Underlying Exile pain unseen by both partners.

## Insights

- Invite parts language: 'A part of me‚Ä¶' instead of accusations.
- Pause for unblending and Self-access.
- Encourage Self-to-Self dialogue: curiosity, compassion.

**Related:** [[Narrative Therapy]], [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Systems Thinking Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Systems Thinking

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Why do our fights always spiral?'
> B: 'Because you won‚Äôt drop things.'
> A: 'I push because you avoid.'
> B: 'I avoid because you push.'
> A: 'We‚Äôre stuck in a loop.'
> B: 'I don‚Äôt know how to change it.'

## Observations

- Reinforcing feedback loop: pursue ‚Üí withdraw ‚Üí pursue (stronger) ‚Üí withdraw (deeper).
- Delay effects: post-conflict distance increases future sensitivity.

## Dynamics

- Attribution error: each blames the other‚Äôs personality, not the loop.
- No leverage points identified.

## Insights

- Insert a timed pause as a balancing loop (structured break).
- Add meta-communication checkpoints (What loop are we in?).
- Small experiments; measure system response rather than blame.

**Related:** [[Relational Theory]], [[Karpman Drama Triangle]], [[Gottman Method]]

index.name: Boundary Models Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Boundary Models

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Please don‚Äôt read my messages without asking.'
> B: 'I was worried and checked because you were distant.'
> A: 'That crossed a line for me.'
> B: 'I understand; I won‚Äôt do that again.'

## Observations

- Boundary breach justified by anxiety.
- Repair initiated through acknowledgment.

## Dynamics

- Porous boundary rationalized as care.
- Trust erosion unless limits clarified.

## Insights

- State boundary + impact + expectation.
- Negotiate access rules and check-ins.
- Reinforce that boundaries protect connection.

**Related:** [[Consent Culture]], [[Containment Models]], [[Analysis Prompt - Repair Attempts]]

index.name: Transactional Analysis Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Transactional Analysis

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'You‚Äôre late again!'
> B: 'Stop treating me like a child.'
> A: 'If you respected me, you‚Äôd be on time.'
> B: 'Maybe if you weren‚Äôt so controlling‚Ä¶'

## Observations

- A in Critical Parent; B in Rebellious Child.
- Crossed transactions escalate conflict.

## Dynamics

- Game invitation: 'Now I‚Äôve Got You, You Son of a‚Ä¶'.
- Stroke economy skewed toward negative strokes.

## Insights

- Name ego states; invite Adult-to-Adult.
- Make clean contracts: who/what/when/how.
- Balance appreciation with clear requests.

**Related:** [[Nonviolent Communication (NVC)]], [[Karpman Drama Triangle]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Polyvagal Example.md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Polyvagal Theory

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'Why are you ignoring me?'
> B: 'I just can‚Äôt deal with this right now.'
> A: 'So you‚Äôre shutting me out again.'
> B: 'I feel trapped when you raise your voice.'
> A: 'I only raise my voice because I feel desperate.'

## Observations

- A escalates into sympathetic mobilization (fight energy).
- B shifts into dorsal vagal shutdown (avoidance).
- Cycle of pursue (A) vs withdraw (B).

## Dynamics

- Mismatched states lead to misattunement.
- Both partners interpret survival strategies as rejection.

## Insights

- Encourage explicit 'pause' agreements when dysregulated.
- B can signal presence nonverbally to reduce A‚Äôs panic.
- A can soften protest with needs language (NVC).

**Related:** [[Attachment Theory]], [[Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)]], [[Analysis Prompt - Attachment]]

index.name: Trauma-Informed Care Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Trauma-Informed Care

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'I can‚Äôt handle surprise feedback sessions.'
> B: 'We thought spontaneity kept it casual.'
> A: 'It spikes my anxiety.'
> B: 'Let‚Äôs schedule and share agenda ahead of time.'

## Observations

- Predictability and choice are core to safety.
- Unexpected intensity triggers hypervigilance.

## Dynamics

- Good intent without safety design undermines trust.
- Opportunity to embed choice/collaboration.

## Insights

- Add transparency: agendas, timing, opt-outs.
- Offer alternatives and pacing options.
- Use strengths-based, non-pathologizing framing.

**Related:** [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Consent Culture]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Somatic Experiencing Example (Long).md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üó£ Example Analysis: Somatic Experiencing

## Transcript Excerpt

> A: 'My chest tightens when we argue.'
> B: 'My stomach drops and I go numb.'
> A: 'I can‚Äôt think clearly.'
> B: 'I want to run away.'
> A: 'Maybe we can slow down.'

## Observations

- High activation; limited cognitive bandwidth.
- Incomplete defensive responses (fight/flight/freeze).

## Dynamics

- Escalation sustained by unprocessed activation.
- Attempts to resolve content without regulation.

## Insights

- Titrate: micropauses, orienting, pendulation.
- Resource before content (touch object, lengthen exhale).
- Complete small defensive impulses (press, step, shake).

**Related:** [[Polyvagal Theory]], [[Trauma-Informed Care]], [[Analysis Prompt - Conflict]]

index.name: Tagging System.md
index.content:
<!-- @format -->

# üè∑ Tagging System

This vault uses a **controlled set of tags** to maintain consistency.

---

## Core Tags

- `framework` ‚Üí Theoretical models (e.g., [[Polyvagal Theory]])
- `prompt` ‚Üí Structured instructions for analysis
- `template` ‚Üí Pre-built reusable structures
- `reference` ‚Üí Reading lists, resources, example conversations
- `meta` ‚Üí Guidelines, structure, system notes

---

## Additional Tags (Optional)

- `analysis` ‚Üí Deep dives or worked examples
- `reflection` ‚Üí Personal notes and journaling
- `example` ‚Üí Example transcripts, case notes

---

## Usage Rules

- Apply **at least one core tag** to every note.
- Use **lowercase** for all tags.
- Avoid creating ad-hoc tags ‚Äî extend only if needed.
